title: UATX/MOSAIC Calculus
text:
This is the home page for both terms of the two-term UATX/MOSAIC Calculus sequence. The course has no specific pre-requisites and is suited both to those who have no previous experience with Calculus and those who have taken an AP or IB year-long calculus sequence. The UATX Calculus sequence is designed to replace the entire multi-term traditional sequence—Calc I, II, III, differential equations, linear algebra—for STEM students and is highly relevant to economics, biology and medicine, data science, public policy, physics, and chemistry. It does not emphasize “pure” (theoretical) mathematics or proof.
Please read the Basics page for course policies and such.
Homework submission link

title: UATX/MOSAIC Calculus
text:
Course outline

First term (10 weeks, winter term)

Preliminaries: Quantities, spaces, functions, notation, computing
Modeling: General techniques used in constructing models, that is, building mathematical representations of real-world objects.
Differentiation/anti-differentiation and applications of derivatives.

Second term (10 weeks, spring term)

Linear algebra (approx 3 weeks). High-dimensional spaces and their residents, projection, decomposition, transformation
Accumulation (approx 3 weeks). Taking information about change of state and turning it into information about state.
Dynamics (approx 3 weeks). Modeling state as it evolves in time.

title: UATX/MOSAIC Calculus
text: Day-by-day schedule

title: UATX/MOSAIC Calculus
text:
Week 1

Tuesday April 1
Review: Objects and operators in calculus
Topics: This is the start of a new Block about representing high-dimensional spaces and basic operations on their inhabitants: Vectors and subspaces.
Reading: MOSAIC Calculus Chap 28 and reading questions
Assignment Day 31: Vectors and pairs of vectors. Due on Friday. (The “Day 31” refers to this being the 31st day of 60 in the two-term calculus course.)


Thursday April 3
Modeling topic: Walking uphill
Modeling topic: Factory production


Friday April 4
Linear combinations of vectors
Reading: MOSAIC Calculus Chap 29 and reading questions
Assignment due: Chapter 28 Exercises

title: MOSAIC Assignment 31
text:
Background software: the man behind the curtain





You likely won’t understand these two programs. They are needed to support the rest of the exercises, but are written in a standard dialect of R.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: MOSAIC Assignment 31
text:
Basic operations

Use vec() to create a vector from individual components (scalars). Example:


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Use rvec() to create a random vector of the specified dimension.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Use the %dot% operator to calculate the dot product.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Exercise 1 Write three test cases for %dot% using vectors for which you can easily find the value by eye.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: MOSAIC Assignment 31
text:
Write these functions and tests

Exercise 2 Use %dot%, sqrt(), and / to calculate the length of a vector

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.







Solution






veclen <- function(v) sqrt(v %dot% v)





Exercise 3 Write three tests for length() on vectors where you already know the answer.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


Exercise 4 Write a function, unitvec() that takes a vector as an input and returns the same vector but with unit magnitude.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.






Tip






unitvec <- function(vec) {
  vec/length(vec)
}





Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Here’s a test that I invented. See if it works in any dimension 2 or greater$

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Explain the result of my test.



Exercise 5 Use %dot%, sqrt(), *, and / to calculated the cosine of the angle between two vectors.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.






Solution






cang <- function(v, w) {
  (v %dot% w) / (veclen(v) * veclen(w))
}






Write these tests for cang() for cases where you already know the answer:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


Exercise 6 Application. The correlation coefficient is a dot product. I’ll write the function for you so that you can use the tilde notation from QR2.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Test this out on any data frame and pair of variables you like.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Explain whether the results correspond or not.

title: MOSAIC Assignment 31
text:
Orthogonality

Exercise 7 Create vectors that are orthogonal to each of these and confirm your answer using cang()

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


Exercise 8 Here’s a function (written in jibberish that you won’t yet understand) but which will construct a vector orthogonal to any vector or set of vectors.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Write some tests on vectors you create of various dimensions and find out whether dtk_ortho() works or not.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Write the test code in the above chunk and explain what you found here.
